conclusion: Determine if the speed difference between objects A and B is continuously increasing.
The v-t graph for object A is a curve starting at the origin, reaching maximum velocity, then decreasing to zero at t1.
The v-t graph for object B is similar to A but lies below Aâ€™s graph and also decreases to zero at t1.
At t=0, both objects start from rest with initial velocities v_A = 0 and v_B = 0.
Both objects increase their velocities over time, with A reaching a higher peak velocity than B.
After reaching peak velocities, both objects decelerate back to zero at t1.
The difference in speed is given by v_A - v_B, starting at zero at t=0.
As time progresses, object A accelerates more quickly, increasing the speed difference.
The speed difference reaches a maximum when A's velocity is at its maximum compared to B.
As velocities decrease, the speed difference decreases, reaching zero at t1.
Diagram shows the speed difference increasing, peaking, then decreasing.
The speed difference is not continuously increasing; it increases, peaks, and decreases.
